awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: A case study of evolution of epigenetic regulators post-gene duplication: Understanding EMBRYONIC FLOWER2-mediated gene regulation in a moss
awd_abstract_narration:
Gene duplication is an important source of novel genetic material on which evolution can act. The novel functions may partially include the original function or may be entirely novel. In the case of the EMBRYONIC FLOWER2 (EMF2) proteins in mosses, the newly duplicated genes may target new genes for repression or they may each target a subset of the original targets. This study is of scientific importance because it will serve as a model to understand how the function of regulatory genes change after a gene duplication event. Moreover, the EMF2 proteins are part of a protein complex that is important in controlling the life cycles of land plants. Thus, understanding the evolution of EMF2-mediated gene regulation will provide a better understanding of the developmental evolution of terrestrial plant life. The EMF2 genes, however, are not only important in plant evolution- they are necessary in animal development. Humans with mutated EMF2 genes or with the wrong amount of EMF2 protein will often develop cancer. Although humans and plants are distantly related, uncovering the conserved mechanisms behind EMF2 gene regulation will contribute to our understanding of human disease. Additional impacts include mentoring and training of undergraduates, along with outreach to K-12 schools and the general public.

     Gene duplication is important because it is the primary mechanism through which novel protein functions arise. This study aims to understand the role gene duplication has played in the evolution of gene regulation. The EMF2 genes are important gene regulators, ensuring that genes are turned off and remain off at the appropriate time during development. The EMF2 genes have undergone duplications during the evolution of many plant lineages. One set of duplication events has produced three copies of the EMF2 genes in Physcomitrella, a model moss species for which powerful genetic and genomic resources are available. The goals of this project are: 1) To understand the evolution of the EMF2 genes in the moss lineage by phylogenetic analysis of gene duplication events; 2) To understand the function of each of the three Physcomitrella EMF2 genes by analyzing mutants in these genes; and 3) To understand how the Physcomitrella gene duplications have modified the EMF2 gene regulation mechanism by determining which genes are targeted by each EMF2 copy and by determining whether this EMF2 targeting results in gene activation or repression. Overall, this study will provide an understanding of the evolution of gene regulation post-gene duplication.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of the project was to understand how the EMBRYONIC FLOWER2 (EMF2) genes have evolved and how they regulate development in the moss, Physcomitrella patens. There were three main goals for this project. (1) Understand the evolution of EMF2 proteins in mosses and of PRC2 proteins in eukaryotes. (2) Characterize the function of the EMF2 genes during P. patens development. (3) Identify P. patens EMF2-targeted genes regulated by PRC2.

We started by cloning the EMF2 genes out of mosses to understand how these genes have evolved in this group of plants. After finding that EMF2 was likely a single-copy gene in the most recent common ancestor of mosses and then duplicated in a lineage-specific manner, we decided to investigate the evolution of the EMF2 genes in eukaryotes to determine if this evolutionary pattern was unique to the mosses. We also explored the evolution of the three other PRC2 proteins in eukaryotes: CURLY LEAF (CLF), FERTILIZATION-INDEPENDENT ENDOSPERM (FIE), and ARABIDOPSIS MULTICOPY SUPRESSOR OF IRA1 (MSI1).

We found that three different moss lineages had independent gene duplications in the EMF2 genes. The gene duplications leading to the threeEMF2 genes in Physcomitrella were recent, lineage-specific gene duplications. After detecting three different lineage-specific gene duplication events in the moss EMF2 genes, we wanted to investigate how often gene duplications have occurred in eukaryote PRC2 proteins. We detected gene duplication events in all four PRC2 core proteins: CLF, FIE, EMF2, and MSI1.

We found multiple copies of the CLF genes in both vertebrates and in flowering plants. Flowering plants possess either two or three copies of the CLF genes. CLF duplicated once in the ancestor of flowering plants to produce two separate gene lineages in flowering plants. One of these two copies duplicated twice more—once in the bean family, Fabaceae, and once in the mustard family, Brassicaceae. This second, lineage-specific gene duplication event explains the presence of a third copy of the CLF genes in the model plant species,Arabidopsis.

The EMF2 genes also duplicated in the animal and plant lineages. We were only able to detect one gene duplication event in animals. However, there were multiple gene duplication events in plants. One gene duplication occurred in the grass family, producing two copies of the EMF2 genes in most grasses. There was an additional EMF2 duplication in the Panicoid grasses. The EMF2 genes also duplicated independently in eudicots. Most eudicots possess two copies of the EMF2 genes, except members of the Brassicaceae family. As with theCLF genes, another gene duplication event occurred in this plant family to produce three copies of the EMF2 genes. In addition to gene duplications, we found that the EMF2 genes have been lost independently in some invertebrates, fungi, and algae. 

There were multiple, large-scale gene duplications in the MSI1 genes in animals, plants, and fungi. The first of the plant MSI1 gene duplications occurred prior to the most recent common ancestor of land plants and green algae. Both of these lineages duplicated once more within the flowering plants, and one of each of the resulting gene pairs then duplicated once more in the Brassicaceae family. 

In addition to studying the evolution of the PRC2 proteins, we made single knockout mutants of all three copies of the P. patens EMF2 genes to determine whether these genes have experienced functional divergence after their recent duplications. We phenotyped the P. patens single mutants by taking multiple sets of images of approximately 30 plants of each of the wild type (WT) and mutant lines. These images were analyzed to determine how the gene deletions affected P. patens development. We analyzed moss colony size at each time point as well as growth rate. We also characterized the overall appearance of each of the moss colonies based on how much protonemata and gametophore tissue were present. 

Mutant plants of the three EMF2 copies had differential growth of protonemata and gametophore tissue compared to WT.  Our results suggest that the three Physcomitrella EMF2 genes have diverged functionally despite arising from a recent set of gene duplications.

Finally, in order to understand the WT gene expression pattern in four of the P. patens tissue types (protonemata, gametophores, sporophyte-bearing gametophores, and sporophytes), we generated WT transcriptomes for these P. patens tissues. We extracted RNA from these tissue types and generated and sequenced RNA-Seq libraries. These are being made available for other P. patens researchers.

Dr. Stephen Yee completed his PhD in Plant Biology and Computational Genetics. He trained 7 undergraduates in from moss identification and phylogenetic systematics, functional analyses of gene function, molecular tools and techniques and cutting edge microscopy. Five of these undergraduates have continued in graduate school in developmental genetics and evolutionary genetics; the other 3 are in medical school. Stephen's dissertation will be published as three independent publications including undergraduate co-authors.
